awd_titl_txt: Construction and Field-Testing of 16 Broadband Ocean Bottom Seismographs for the OBSIC Fleet
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding Earth processes, such as mantle dynamics and plate tectonics, and the phenomena they produce, such as earthquakes, volcanoes, and planet-scale elemental cycling, requires sustained deployments of seafloor instruments, since ~ 70% of the earth's surface is covered by the oceans. While data from land-based instruments can tell us much about large-scale structure and earthquake activity under the oceans, many questions related to the structure and dynamics of mid-ocean ridges, hot-spots, subduction zones, and continental margins can only be addressed by data acquired with Ocean Bottom Seismometers (OBSs). Discovery is advanced by an efficient, effective means for scientists to acquire ocean-bottom seismic data. 

The Ocean Bottom Seismometer Instrument Center (OBSIC) at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) provides seafloor seismographs and at-sea technical support to all U.S. investigators whose research would benefit from seafloor seismic observations. OBSIC currently operates a fleet of 124 Ocean-Bottom Seismographs (OBS), of which 30 are short-period and the remaining 94 are broadband units of varied type. This award support construction of 16 new broadband ocean-bottom seismographs that will bring the total OBSIC fleet to 150 and the broadband OBS count to 110. The new OBS will carry a Nanometrics Trillium T-240 3-component broadband seismometer and a Differential Pressure Gauge, be deployable to 6000 m, and have an endurance of at least 15 months. The OBS will be equipped with a low-powered Seascan clock disciplined by a power-cycled Chip-Scale Atomic Clock that will provide improved timing accuracy without an undue power penalty. Overall, these new instruments are an important enhancement to the NSF-supported OBS fleet, and will increase OSBIC's capacity to field OBS arrays with greater numbers of instruments, to support additional contemporaneous experiments, and to reduce the wait-time for the deployment of funded experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project funded the design and construction of 16 broadband Ocean-Bottom Seismographs (OBS) for the NSF-funded Ocean Bottom Seismic Instrument Center (OBSIC).  We refer to this new OBS design as the “Angler” OBS.  The specifications of the Angler OBS are listed in Table 1. The 16 Angler OBS built with this award has expanded the fleet of OBS operated by OBSIC, thereby reducing the wait-time for investigators with funded experiments.  In addition, the seismometers on these OBS have self-noise at or below the USGS Low-Noise model out to ~100 s period, meaning they are significantly better for recording teleseismic surface waves than the majority of the OBS in the OBSIC fleet, which are equipped with seismometers with much higher self-noise in the surface-wave band.

As part of the qualification process for the Angler OBS design, we carried out tank tests at the WHOI AVAST center, and deployed an Angler OBS alongside a proven "ARRA" OBS for ~4 days offshore WHOI. See attached PDF file for details. The tank tests were designed to test how the seismometer dropped from the deployment arm on the OBS frame, and evaluate the OBS release system.  For the offshore test, we used divers to monitor the OBS attitude on the seafloor, the seismometer release from the Angler OBS frame, and seismometer lift-off on recovery. Comparison of the data from the Angler OBS with the ARRA OBS showed that the former was operating as predicted.

Ten Angler OBS equipped with Nanometrics Trillium T-240 seismometers were deployed in March/April 2023 as part of a 53 OBS array emplaced offshore the Galapagos Islands.  Six Anglers equipped with Nanometrics Trillium T-120 seismometers will be deployed in early 2025 for a combined seismic and EM survey of the Cocos Plate.

Table 1. Angler OBS Specifications

Physical Attributes

Two 7075-T6 aluminum 9” x 38” pressure housings holding: (i) data-logger, WHOI-designed controllers, acoustic release board, batteries, and (ii) acoustic release board, lithium batteries. A 16“ aluminum sphere holds seismometer and leveling system. Leveling is via motorized gimbals. Air weight with/without anchor is 1,509 lbs/1,234 lbs. Syntactic foam floatation consisting of two 24” x 34” x 17” blocks with combined in-air weight of 675 lbs and a combined 375 lbs.

Seismometer

Either a Nanometrics Trillium T-240 (10 units) or T-120 Horizon (6 units) in with a WHOI-designed active-leveling system.  T-240 seismometer has a velocity response that is flat from 240 s to 35 Hz. T-120 Horizon seismometer has a velocity response that is flat from 120 s to 150 Hz. For both seismometers self-noise is below the seismic low-noise model from ~0.01 – 10 Hz. Power consumption is 650 mW (T-240) or 230 mW (T-120). For the T-240, the clip level us 15 mm/s up to 1.5 Hz. For the T-120, the clip level is 16 mm/s up to 10 Hz and 0.12 g above 10 Hz.  No mass lock required for either sensor. When deployed, the seismometer package is mechanically decoupled from motion of the OBS frame, and is shielded from seafloor currents.

Pressure Sensor 

Differential Pressure Gauge (DPG)

Data-Logger

Quanterra Q8 6-channel data engine with 24-bit A/Ds. Simultaneous sample rates of 1,000, 500, 250, 200, 100, 50, 40, 20, 10, and 1 Hz.  Dual (internal standard and external optional) removable USB flash drives, typical 32GB and 64GB. 32GB high-reliability SLC SD card and 32GB high-reliability eMMC. All remotely accessible. Built-in 3-axis ±2g MEMS Accelerometer, separately and synchronously digitized.

Flotation 

Syntactic Foam

Clock

Continuously powered DTCXO Seascan clock with power-cycled Teledyne Chip-Scale Atomic Clock (CSAC) to measure Seascan frequency.

Battery  

Lithium Primary battery pack for ~18 months recording at 100 Hz. Separate keep-alive battery for clock.

Endurance

~18 months

Max. Depth 

6,000 m

Release

Dual, Redundant Acoustic Burn-Wire Releases

Operation

Operated in closed-housing mode i.e. programming of acquisition parameters, offloading of data, clock setting, etc, all done through penetrators. Pressure tubes carry an electronic vacuum gauge to ensure tubes are well sealed prior to deployment.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/12/2024
Modified by: John A Collins

    Figure 1
  • Close-up of the Angler seismometer after it released from the deployment arm. It is sitting on its three legs as designed.

    John A Collins
    Figure 2
  • A full assembled Angler OBS on the back deck of the WHOI-owned vessel R/V Tioga prior to deployment in shallow waters offshore Woods Hole. The seismometer is mounted on its deployment arm. The seismometer is dropped from the arm via a corrodible link after the seismometer lands on the seafloor.
    Hannah Brewer
